doc.after: The Gospel of John has been seen as especially aimed at emphasizing Jesus' divinity, presenting Jesus as the Logos, pre-existent and divine, from its first words, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God."[John 1:1][77] The Gospel of John ends with Thomas's apparent confession of faith to Jesus, "My Lord and my God!"[John 20:28][72] There is no significant tendency among modern scholars to deny that John 1:1 and John 20:28 identify Jesus with God.[78] John also portrays Jesus as the agent of creation of the universe.[79]
